information_requirement: Is an adversary executing arbitrary code on corporate mobile devices by exploiting client application vulnerabilities? (TA0041 - Execution)

evidence.description: A mobile device's messaging or browser application initiates an unusual network connection or spawns an unexpected child process following user interaction with a link or file delivered via SMS/MMS/iMessage, indicative of a one-click or zero-click exploit.
evidence.nai: Corporate Wi-Fi network gateways, Mobile Device Management (MDM) servers, Endpoint mobile devices
evidence.action: Monitor Zeek dns.log for requests from mobile devices to newly registered domains (NRDs) or domains with a high entropy score. Correlate these DNS requests with subsequent outbound connections in conn.log to non-standard ports or known malicious IP addresses. On endpoints with EDR/MDM, establish a baseline of normal process relationships (e.g., parent-child processes) for common applications like browsers and messaging clients. Alert on deviations, such as Safari spawning a shell process (/bin/sh). Use statistical analysis to identify devices exhibiting an anomalous increase in outbound connections or data transfer volume immediately following a DNS lookup to a suspicious domain.

evidence.description: A mobile device experiences a sudden, unexplained system crash or reboot, potentially followed by the installation of an unauthorized application or configuration profile, consistent with a buffer overflow exploit delivered via a peer-to-peer protocol like AirDrop.
data_sources: Mobile Device Management (MDM) application inventory logs
Mobile Device Management (MDM) configuration profile logs
evidence.nai: Mobile Device Management (MDM) servers, Endpoint mobile devices, Corporate Wi-Fi network gateways
evidence.action: Ingest and analyze mobile OS crash logs from MDM. Create a time-series visualization of crash events per OS version and device model to identify anomalous spikes that could indicate a targeted exploit campaign. Following a crash alert, trigger an automated MDM policy to query the device's application and profile inventory. Compare the new inventory against the last known-good snapshot to identify unauthorized additions. Use frequency analysis on installed application names across the fleet; an app name that is statistically rare or unique to a single device post-crash is highly suspicious. Monitor Zeek conn.log for any subsequent beaconing activity from the crashed device to unusual external IP addresses, which would indicate successful C2 establishment.
